title: How are cultural relativism and ethnocentrism related? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m hardly an expert on the topic, but I’ll share some thoughts. A “cultural relativist” is someone who doubts that there exists any non-human value system or moral code. All such things are human inventions and, of course, standards for “right” and “wrong” vary incredibly depending on which society or historical period one happens to live in. Thus, since all values are culture-based one should refrain from praising or blaming the moral beliefs and practices of the past or of present societies of which you are not a member. If you, for some reason, want to condemn long dead people for something (say, owning slaves) or express your disgust at social practices in other countries today (say, female circumcision) then—since there exists no universal moral code—you are being “ethnocentric”. This means that you are judging these things by your culture’s values. I don’t think there’s anything necessarily bad about doing this (unless you are convinced that your society knows what’s truly right and wrong and any person or society who thinks otherwise is wicked). So, to sum up: Cultural relativists are not inclined to judge the value systems of other peoples and societies at all. If they do, they know that they are being ethnocentric (and this generally makes them uncomfortable). Many ethnocentric people aren’t made uncomfortable by condemning other peoples or practices because they tacitly assume that their culture’s value system is superior (even if they reject morality as dictated by God or Reason).
